Subjective: Dizziness x3 days. Onset: waking up, getting out of bed. Sensation: room spinning, some lightheadedness. Worse with head movement, better when sitting still. Nausea present, no vomiting. No headache. No hearing loss/tinnitus. No speech difficulty. No limb weakness. Palpitations noted when dizzy, resolves spontaneously. No syncope, but feels light-headed. Recent cold. Negatives: No trauma, no recent illness requiring bed rest. Social: No smoking, no alcohol, no drugs. ICE (Concern): Fear of brain tumor due to friend's symptoms. Request: Wants to get rid of dizziness.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/70, Pulse 62 bpm, regular. Neuro: Cranial nerves intact (face sensation, eye closure, eyebrow raise, teeth clench, cheek puff, tongue protrusion). Motor: Shoulder shrug, muscle flex, arm hold with eyes closed normal. Finger-to-nose testing normal. Gait: Normal walking, tandem gait normal. Eyes: No nystagmus with visual tracking. Head Impulse Test (HIT): Negative bilaterally. Positional Testing: Dix-Hallpike maneuver provokes vertigo and nystagmus (left > right).
Assessment: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV). Ruled out: Brain tumor, other central causes of vertigo.
Plan: 1. Explanation of BPPV, reassuring it is not a brain tumor. 2. Epley maneuver performed in clinic today. 3. Instructions for home exercises via thuisarts.nl. 4. Advice: Avoid provoking movements if possible initially. 5. Safety netting: Contact if symptoms worsen significantly or new neurological symptoms develop. 6. Follow-up: As needed.
